title: Documentation: make the 'Using Models in Your Migrations' example code more concise.
body:
Along with this change simply being more concise, I think it's also preferable that we teach people to use the `update_all` method where possible instead of:

    Product.all.each do |product|
      product.update_attributes!(:flag => 'false')
    end

This example above can get *extremely* slow with a lot of records because it first loads all the products into memory before writing to the database.

title: corrected some misspelling
body: @vijaydev

title: fix `bundle exec rails new app` not running `bundle install` properly
body:
the issue can be reproduce with:

    printf "source :rubygems\n\ngem 'rails'\n" > Gemfile
    bundle install
    bundle exec rails new app1
    rails new app2
    ls -l app*/Gemfile.lock

In the case of `app1` the command `bundle install` was run in context of already loaded Gemfile, which had totally different effect then expected.

This also fixes #6314.

title: add tests and external file backtrace for Routing::Mapper#draw
Moving number helper from ActionView to Active Support
body:
Hi,

In an earlier pull request I hoped we could decouple ActiveSupport from ActionView:

https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/5675

It was suggested by @josevalim that instead of that approach, we move the number helpers from ActionView to ActiveSupport.  In addition to his suggestion, this approach was a feature request in a separate issue:

https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/3214

In this pull request I've moved the functionality from NumberHelper in ActionView to ActiveSupport and added the methods to Numeric.  So instead of including NumberHelper and writing "number_to_human(123)", you could just include ActiveSupport and write "123.to_human".  The original NumberHelper methods are all left in place and accept the same options and behave the same (and just pass through to the AS implementation in Numeric).

Other interested parties may include: @carlosantoniodasilva, @fxn, and @yfeldblum.

Let me know if you'd like any changes to this implementation.

Thanks,
Andrew.

title: Changing gitignore template to ignore files with sensitive data by default
body: Not sure if is valid but I'm opening this PR to discuss it. I think it could be useful to avoid security issues by default.

title: Created a Raw handler for templates.
body:
This addresses the issue brought up in #2394.

I built this based on [@josevalim's suggestion](https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/2394#issuecomment-1920786), which involves creating a raw template and adding a deprecation message for default template handlers.

One issue with this as it stands is that the tests now throw some warnings; I should probably fix those up, but I wanted to get feedback on my test and this code first. I'm 99% sure that it's all good, but I've never dived into this part of Rails before.

title: require "rubygems" is obsolete in Ruby 1.9.3
body:
Requiring RubyGems does nothing on Ruby 1.9.3, since it is already loaded:

```
ruby -e 'p require "rubygems"'
false
```

So, I think we can remove it safely from boot.rb and other files, since Rails 4 will require Ruby 1.9.3+.

title: Remove ActiveSupport::Cache::MemCacheStore
body: memcache-client was deprecated in favor of dalli in 2010, now users should be using dalli_store instead of the old mem_cache_store

title: Add Object#send_if_responds_to
body: This should simplify a lot of our code, similarly to what `try` does.

title: Improve and cleanup a bit partial renderer
body:
Some refactoring for collection rendering:

* Remove post template assignment: there is no need for this assignment, given we are rendering a collection with different templates.
* Remove segments array with `<<` in favor of `Array#map`
* Use local vars whenever possible, including a local var for indexing
* Cache local template keys, remove defaults from find_template

This is somewhat related to the discussion in #6006. [Here are some quick benchmarks](https://gist.github.com/2553080). If it's necessary I can try to prepare another.

@josevalim could you take a look please?

Any feedback is welcome. Thanks!

title: 3 2 stable guides fix
body:
Update guides for whitelist security.  Not applicable on master.

Closes #6286.

title: Number helpers defaults
body:
This uses the `:en` locale as default fallback for number helpers, such as `number_with_precision` and brothers. The overall idea is that we should always have fallbacks when using such helpers, instead of letting them raise different errors due to missing arguments. The implementation basically fetches the defaults for :en and merges the translations with the given locale.

After some discussion it seems a good path to use the default `:en` translations that ship with the framework as fallbacks instead of constants, to avoid the duplicated defaults. I'd like some feedback on this, thanks.

Closes #4420, #2802, #2890.

title: Update activesupport/lib/active_support/json/encoding.rb
body: urgent: ESCAPED_CHARS doesn't return escaped html symbols - wrong implementation!

title: set escaping HTML in json encoding to +true+
body:
related #6277 @spastorino @josevalim are OK to turn it true by default I :thumbsup: it too, this will mitigate some XSS holes - check showcases I made in that issue. but seems @wycats didn't like this idea and proposed me to use escaping on the client side. It looks a little bit weird to me(escaping HTML on client side). I see no single reason to send smht like this ``` {"body": "

body

"} ``` it's definitely not the Rails way. Anyway, it's just an option that saves JSON-backend based apps from XSS and lame code either :).

title: clean the erros if an object that includes validation  is duped.
body: If an istance that include validation is duped it keep track of errors of its 'parent', because both errors instances point to the same ActiveModel::Errors instance. This happen when before to call dup, ``` save or valid?``` is called. This Fixes #5953 and it was discussed on the pull request https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/5958
